div.head:
Embleme 47. Of the Secrets of Nature.
A Wolfe coming from the East, and a Dogge from the West werry'd
one another.

lg.l: From th' East a Wolfe, from the West a Dogge appears,
Which raging fall together by the ears,
Choler inciting they each other tear,
And gaping seem as if they rabid were:
These are two stones, which you may soone acquire,
For all men may obtaine them at desire.

div.head: Discourse 47.
div.ab:
The Philosophers have in many places made mention of two stones given to us
gratis, as Isaack, Arnold, and others, amongst whome Avicenne sayth they lye in-
dung neglected and rejected by the vulgar, which, if they be joynd together, are
able to complete the Magistery: Some men extoll the occidentall Mercury, which
hath præferrd itselfe before gold, and overcome it: But the Author of the ad
vice of the wedlocke of Sol and Luna out of the epistle of Aristotle doth-
best of all describe the two stones, where hee sayth: That there are two-
principall stones of this art, the white and the red of wonderfull nature: at
the setting of the Sunne the white begins to appear upon the surface of the
waters, hiding itselfe till midnight, and afterwards declines to the bottome: But
the red operates contrariwise, it beginning to ascend upon the waters at the
rising of the Sunne till noone, and then descends to the bottome. These-
Stones therefore are the aforesayd Eagles sent by Jupiter from Delphi;-
These allso are the wolfe and dogge coming from different or opposite parts-
of the earth, which bitt and werry'd one the other, and both became mad, as-
Rhasis in his epistle declares: These stones are the most true Bezoar,-
whereof the east Indyes send the best, drawne from the bowells of-
wild beasts, the West Indyes yeild another but of lesse efficacy, had
at peruana out of animalls made tame; Soe the East aaffoards a-
most fierce wolfe, the west a dogge familiar to men, that is, Sulphur
comes from the East, Mercury from the Western tract, whereof this is
gentle and tractable, that cholericke and angry; which two, when
first the find one another, doe fall together by the ears: and-
the dogge being of notable bignesse obtains the first victory,-
prostrating the wolfe, and bringing him to deaths doore: But the
wolfe recovering strength afterwards overthrowes the dogge, and be
ing cast downe never leaves him till hee be utterly killd and dead;-
In the meane time receiving from the dogge noe lesse wounds nor lesse
mortall, than hee gave him, till they werry one another to death: As-
touching the wolfe Sayth Rosinus to Euthicia: That hee is a fortifyd
souldier the conquerour of two, of much esteeme and most intense
strength, perforating bodyes when hee meets with them, and is white
in apparition, red by experiment, and is the man which tooke Luna
to wife, whome some men suppose to be gold of a most pretious con
nexion and composition, whose congealed part is never dissolved, nor
footsteps or impressions defaced, which God hath freely bestowed-
upon the pious and elect Philosophers: You must know, that nature-
hath gotten an æquall as an enemy. These are his words. And a little after
hee sayth: That Sulphur is most strong, and fighting against fire-
which it containes and is contained: for a most pretious colour proceeds
from them being joynd together, and that Sulphur, which is naturally
volatile, can never afterwards flye away, because the Soule hath--
Discourse 47.
perforated it, in like manner the tincture of the Soule hath both perforated
and is mixed with the body, and the body hath contained the soule, and
restrained the naturall part from flying. And then to one demanding which
of the stones was strongest, hee answers: That stone which is noe stone
is stronger than the other enemy: but the red is stronger than that-
which strengthened its companions by its fortitude. The Orientall wolfe is
therefore stronger than the Occidentall dogge, though hee obtaine not the
victory effectually, but perisheth together with the enemy: but the tinging
poyson is producd from both: The differente between a wolfe and dogge is
small, a Mastive or great dogge representing the forme and shape of a
wolfe, soe as to seeme a wolfe originally, but made tame by long progene
ration: After the same manner Sulphur and Mercury doe little differ one
from the other, because that proceeds from this, or this from that: Mercury
did indeed begett Sulphur, but Sulphur purged Mercury and made it soe:
Concerning these the same Rosinus, the quæstion being asked, from-
whence comes its colour? answers, from the most intense bitternesse of it:
and againe. From whence comes its bitternesse and intension? hee answers
from the impurity of its metall: And againe: Is its red colour never su
pereminent? hee answers, Yes: And againe: Is it allso never hotter than-
fire? hee answer; Fire in respect of it is as water in respect of fire: And
againe: Is it not stronger than fire? hee answers, not. And againe: Why-
therefore doe you affirme it to be stronger than fire? hee answers, because
fires meeting together doe one destroy the other. It is therefore manifest-
that one becomes the food and aliment of the other, and soe much as one
decreaseth, soe much the other increaseth, till that which increaseth præ
vayles, and the Dragon devoures the serpent: In great fights it often times
happens, that they that undergoe the greater slaughter doe winne the
feild and victory; Soe allso though the dogge lay prostrate, yet was not-
alltogether overcome, hee holding his enemy soe fast, that hee could not
line without him, nor hee dye without the other. . . . . . .
